Every product that appears on the Strategist has been independently selected by our rather obsessive staff (and you can read more about our editorial guidelines here). That means our mighty team of journalists is constantly testing products, interviewing experts and people with good taste for recommendations, tracking trends and launches, and keeping one eye open for actually good deals. We’re constantly chatting among ourselves, sharing shopping tips and one-of-a-kind finds. We’ve even created a Slack channel, called #strat-chats, for the express purpose of talking about the things we’re most excited to buy.
Each of our writers has deep expertise and experience around their subject matter, and their knowledge often extends far beyond what they’re doing at work. (Take, for example, our fitness writer, who logged over 1,900 miles of running last year, or our travel writer, who dabbled in van life for eight months.) And though we always endeavor to show our work in our guides and reviews, here, we wanted to take a moment to show off the people behind the product recommendations.
Arielle is a writer covering wardrobe basics and personal care, and she regularly contributes to The Strategist Beauty Brief. Arielle joined the Strategist in 2020 and previously wrote about style at Texas Monthly. She’s tested showerhead water filters, electric toothbrushes, and water flossers (and thinks you don’t need to spend more than $100 — or even $50 — on a bidet to change your life).
Find all of Arielle’s work here.
Read how Arielle picks her picks here.
Liza is a senior writer covering personal care and gear for kids and babies, especially toys. She joined the Strategist in 2019 and is a former writer for GQ and an accomplished illustrator. Liza used to be a French teacher at a Waldorf school, and she has a soft spot for wooden fake food and Sylvanian Families sets.
Find all of Liza’s work here.
Read how Liza picks her picks here.
Sam is the Strategist’s deals editor and combs the internet for great sales every day as well as on major shopping events like Black Friday and Amazon Prime Day. She was formerly the shop editor for Dwell. According to Sam, if it’s less than 15 percent off, it’s not really on sale.
Find all of Sam’s work here.
Read how Sam picks her picks here.
Tembe has been a writer at the Strategist since 2020, covering beauty. She previously wrote about beauty and culture for Nylon and Elle, and she is the author of the novel Homebodies. Tembe regularly contributes to The Strategist Beauty Brief and has amassed so many beauty products over the years, she built an Ikea Pax system to store them all.
Find all of Tembe’s work here.
Read how Tembe picks her picks here.
Bella is a junior writer, writing about sales, fashion, and home goods. She previously wrote about gifts at Shop Today. Bella has gone deep into the Strategist’s archives to research the underwear, fragrances, and comfortable shoes that famous people actually use.
Find all of Bella’s work here.
Read how Bella picks her picks here.
Katherine is a writer who covers travel and outdoor essentials, including gear for cycling, hiking, and enjoying time outside. She has been an expat in the United States for six years, including eight months living in a van around California and the Southwest, and she flies a lot (usually wearing her Manta sleep mask). She was previously an editor at Paper.
Find all of Katherine’s work here.
Read how Katherine picks her picks here.
Brenley joined the Strategist as a junior writer in 2022, after interning at the site. She writes about beauty, especially bath and body products, and men’s and women’s fashion. Brenley has a knack for discovering surprisingly useful devices, like a headlamp beanie for late-night runs, an easy-to-clean makeup case, and a gadget that takes the tops off aluminum cans.
Find all of Brenley’s work here.
Read how Brenley picks her picks here.
Rachael is a writer based in the United Kingdom. She joined the Strategist in 2021 after interning for the site, and she writes about beauty, especially hair care and grooming. Her go-to beauty secrets are (still) these blood-red drops, which keep her hair fire-engine red, and a good self-tanner. Rachael also regularly contributes to The Strategist Beauty Brief.
Find all of Rachael’s work here.
Read how Rachael picks her picks here.
Kitty is a writer covering beauty, especially makeup, fashion, and gifts. She estimates she has tried over 50 mascaras in her lifetime and believes a good hair dryer can change your life. Kitty also regularly contributes to The Strategist Beauty Brief and runs a personal-shopping newsletter, Worn In, Worn Out.
Find all of Kitty’s work here.
Read how Kitty picks her picks here.
Amelia is the Strategist’s sleep writer, covering mattresses, pillows, and other stuff you need to sleep better. She has been writing about sleep products since 2021, previously as a senior staff writer for Sleepopolis. Amelia estimates she’s laid on over 50 mattresses over the past three years, including her own (a Serta Arctic, ideal for back- and side-sleepers).
Find all of Amelia’s work here.
Read how Amelia picks her picks here.
Jordan is the Strategist’s tech writer, and he covers a wide array of gadgets and how software can help build better relationships with technology in our lives. He’s been covering technology since 2017 and has also written for Wired, Wirecutter, and Reviewed.com. Jordan thinks more people would be into e-readers if they gave them a chance. (He’s personally tested ten.)
Find all of Jordan’s work here.
Read how Jordan picks his picks here.
Jenna is an associate editor at the Strategist, as well as an ASME Next board member and an adjunct professor at New York University. She edits the Strategist print section, including “The Look Book.”
Find all of Jenna’s work here.
Ambar covers women’s fashion, including apparel, sleepwear, shoes, and jewelry. She joined the Strategist as a writer in 2021, and before that worked at NBC and HuffPost. Ambar has a row of Commando bikinis at the very top of her underwear drawer and maintains a vendetta against vermeil. (Just buy the solid gold.)
Find all of Ambar’s work here.
Read how Ambar picks her picks here.
Dominique has been a writer at the Strategist since 2018. She covers wellness, including sex toys and home-office goods; beauty, especially hair tools; and home-bar essentials. She has tested over 20 curling irons, blow-dryers, and straighteners, and contributes to The Strategist Beauty Brief. Dominique is also a writer for “The Approval Matrix.”
Find all of Dominique’s work here.
Read how Dominique picks her picks here.
Lauren joined the Strategist as a writer in 2018. She covers almost everything related to the home, including design moments, baby gear, and all the best bedding. She’s tested 12 towels and 22 sets of bedding, and she thinks linen is best for duvet covers. Lauren was previously an associate editor at Curbed.
Find all of Lauren’s work here.
Read how Lauren picks her picks here.
Jeremy is a writer who covers wellness, including fitness and the gear people use to play outdoors. He’s been writing about the outdoors since 2018 and was previously an editor at Outside. He’s tested over two dozen pairs of running shoes in the last two years and has run over 1,900 miles in those shoes, including 13 races in 2023 (from 5Ks to half-marathons).
Find all of Jeremy’s work here.
Read how Jeremy picks his picks here.
Erin is a writer who covers home décor and furniture. They previously worked as an editor at Garage magazine and reviewed TV, movies, and books for The Nation. They’ve installed 58 square feet of pegboards in their home and use project-management software for home-DIY projects.
Find all of Erin’s work here.
Read how Erin picks their picks here.
Emma is the Strategist’s kitchen and dining writer. She has worked in food media for over nine years, including as an editor at Bon Appétit. She writes a column for Eater on easy weeknight meals for one called “Single Serving” — and she has sliced, diced, chopped, and carved with probably close to 50 different knives.
Find all of Emma’s work here.
Read how Emma picks her picks here.
Ashley is the Strategist’s newsletter editor. She has ten years of experience overseeing newsletter strategy for publications including Vanity Fair, Wired, Teen Vogue, Them, Atlas Obscura, and The Spruce. She has written about running gear, TV, music, and travel for publications including Vulture, Teen Vogue, Self, Lonely Planet, Fodor’s, and TripSavvy.
To read more of Ashley’s work, sign up for the Strategist’s email newsletter here. You can also find some of Ashley’s work here.

Conscious Cup - 8 oz
Ahimsa dishware is built to last a lifetime with no peeling or breaking. To read our full lifetime warranty, click here.
- Dishwasher safe.
- Avoid using abrasive cleaning tools and harsh detergents (including steel wool and dishwasher pods/ powerballs) to preserve the titanium color finish and keep products in optimal condition.
- Stackable design — say bye-bye to clutter!
- Please supervise children at mealtime for safety, especially young children under 3.
- Take care when handling or serving hot foods and liquids.
- Do not microwave.
Designed with busy parents in mind.
Built for a lifetime of health.
Ahimsa is consciously crafted of high quality food-safe stainless steel and titanium. Our dishes are free of BPA (and all bisphenols), PVC, phthalates, lead, siloxanes, melamine and formaldehyde—meaning that harmful chemicals won't transfer into your child's food.
Why stainless steel?
While plastic, melamine and even BPA-free dishware, flatware, and drinkware made for kids is often a go-to choice, science says it’s not the best for their development. Stainless steel, however, brings a healthier, more sustainable, and effortlessly fun option to the table—for life.
Doctor designed, kid approved.
Each Ahimsa piece is intentionally sized to promote early motor skills and confidence, while offering easy measurements for healthy portioning at every age. Kids love our colorful reflective surfaces and won't want to eat with anything else!
Questions? We're here to help.
-
The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) released a report in July 2018 suggesting ways that families can limit exposure to certain chemicals at mealtime, including “the use of alternatives to plastic, such as glass or stainless steel, when possible.” The report explained that “…some additives are put directly in foods, while “indirect” additives may include chemicals from plastic, glues, dyes, paper, cardboard”. Further, “Children are more sensitive to chemical exposures because they eat and drink more, relative to body weight, than adults do, and are still growing and developing.” While stainless steel items meet the recommendation to avoid plastic products in children, Ahimsa® products have the obvious advantage of not breaking like glass.
-
The first years set the stage for healthy habits for the rest of your child’s life. It’s never too early to start.
Balanced Bites Plates:
Our compartment plates are a visual map for parents to plan and for children to learn about the importance of food variety at each meal. Additionally, parents have found by using stainless steel rather than dinnerware that can be microwaved – they are choosing more healthy, fresh foods for their children.Cups:
Ahimsa cups are not only inert stainless steel and therefore, nontoxic and do not leach chemicals – but they are also the perfect size for small hands. The American Academy of Pediatric Dentistry advises that sippy cups should not be used for extended periods of time due to tooth decay. The American Speech-Language-Hearing Association discourages sippy cups because they can interfere with a child’s ability to develop a mature swallowing pattern. We are so happy to offer cups that promote health not only due to their makeup, size and structure – but also to encourage healthy teeth, eating and speech development.Cutlery:
Encouraging children to use utensils during meals helps with pincer grasp and fine motor development. Parents have shared with us that their children often chose not to use their utensils until they started using our brightly colored cutlery and then continued to do so through habit.
-
No. Our steel is durable, so it won’t break or shatter with everyday use, like glass. And it won’t peel, like other colored stainless steel products you’ve seen. We use a special process that allows the colors to naturally occur in the metal.
-
According to the Steel Recycling Institute, steel can be recycled over and over and over again without losing its integrity and requires less energy to recycle than to make anew. Most plastic unfortunately ends up in landfills and it is estimated to take 700 years to decompose. Our special coloring process that allows Ahimsa® products to be fully metal is environmentally friendly, so it does not produce toxic run-off into the ecosystem.

A mom of two, Kary specializes in family mealtime dynamics and eating issues across the spectrum, from breast and bottle feeding challenges and picky eating, to dysphagia, tube feeding, and complex food refusal. Kary has extensive, wide-ranging work experience from outpatient therapy, to pediatric acute care in a high acuity NICU, to in-home settings and Well Child visits, all supporting families and children with eating and swallowing. Kary has worked with thousands of infants and children as they learn to eat, and she has taught parents and medical professionals on this topic for nearly two decades.
Specializing in infant and child feeding, eating, and swallowing, Kim has spent the majority of her career in pediatric acute care at some of the largest children's hospitals on the west coast, focusing specifically on neonatal (NICU) feeding and swallowing, breastfeeding with high-risk infants, and infant/pediatric cardiac rehabilitation. In addition to her hospital-based work, Kim has worked with families struggling with breastfeeding, transitioning to solids, selective/picky eating, tube weaning, and oral motor/chewing. Kim is a mom of two in Michigan.
Dr. Ruiz is a mom of three, a board-certified general pediatrician, and a pediatric gastroenterologist. She completed her undergraduate at Dartmouth College, doctorate of medicine and pediatrics residency at Vanderbilt University, and pediatric gastroenterology fellowship at Stanford University. Dr. Ruiz is an attending pediatric gastroenterologist at Santa Clara Valley Medical Center and an affiliated clinical instructor of pediatric gastroenterology at Lucile Packard Children's Hospital at Stanford. She treats a wide range of children suffering from constipation, abdominal pain, swallowing difficulties, inadequate weight gain, inflammatory bowel disease, fatty liver and other liver diseases, and Celiac disease. In her part-time position at Solid Starts, Dr. Ruiz reviews content for evidence-based accuracy, analyzes choking data and trends, and is a trainer for Solid Starts PRO®.
Dr. Bajowala is a mother of two and a board-certified adult and pediatric allergist and immunologist with a passion for patient education and advocacy. She specializes in the evaluation and management of food allergy, and is a best-selling author on the topic. In her private allergy practice, she helps her young patients overcome food allergies through precision-focused sublingual and oral immunotherapy. In her part-time position at Solid Starts, Dr. Bajowala reviews content for evidence-based accuracy, analyzes allergy data and trends, and is a trainer for Solid Starts PRO®.
Inspired by her mother’s work serving nutritionally vulnerable mothers and infants, Venus is dedicated to bridging nutritional inequities in her work. As a pediatric dietitian in gastroenterology, she works with children with celiac and inflammatory bowel diseases, food allergies, picky eating, and more, while exploring research and program development. Venus completed her Registered Dietitian training at Stanford Medicine and her Masters in Nutrition Science and Policy at Tufts University. Off the clock, she practices her polyglot skills, sings jazz, and subjects her husband to unconventional culinary creations.
As an occupational therapist, Marisa holds advanced certification in feeding, eating, and swallowing, and is also a certified lactation education counselor. With a background in psychiatry and behavioral management, she is passionate about addressing the anxiety commonly felt with feeding—from postpartum breast- and bottle-feeding to complex family mealtime dynamics and caregiver support. Marisa is a mom of three, including twins and enjoys cooking family meals with her dietitian husband, Josh.
Jenny is a mom of three on a quest to help families find joy at the table. Passionate about food and farming, Jenny founded Solid Starts to make it easier for parents to learn how to introduce any food to their baby. Jenny is the creator of the award-winning First Foods® database and the Solid Starts App.

As essential to a summer wardrobe as a swimsuit or sun hat, sandals will take you from your 100-degree commute to your 10,000-step vacation. But a great pair can be surprisingly hard to find. Often, the ones that look chicest leave blisters, while the most comfortable ones leave something to be desired in the style department. But good news: As the Strategist’s resident style writer, I’m rather obsessive (and opinionated) about what makes for a great sandal, and I found many for this list by asking many tasteful women about theirs. You’ll find everything here from Goop-coded Havaianas to dupes for the Row’s $690 Dune flip-flops. (And if you’re looking for more summer shoes to shop, check out our guides to the best espadrilles and flip-flops.)
Update on August 14, 2025
We added a few new pairs, plus confirmed availability and updated prices for all others. Some styles from Camper, Keen, Aerosoles, and Vagabond are on sale.
Flip-flops
New! You can now save this product for later.
First up: a slew of Havaianas. “I might say they are the most Goop-coded Havaianas, but that would give the impression I shop at Goop,” says artist Melly Wirtes. The Slim Crystal Flip Flops are the pair she slips into for walks around the block on the Upper East Side and vacations to South Carolina and Jamaica. It “may be laughable,” but the Slim’s little crystal turns them into something more than just a humble flip-flop, she told me. It helps that it “kind of registers as a neutral on my skin tone (read: fair complexion perpetually slightly sunburned in summer)” in ballet rose. (Meanwhile, she mentally earmarks Havaianas’ Brazil — more on those further down — as “swimming pool/beach/outdoor” flip-flops.)
New! You can now save this product for later.
Unlike standard-issued Havaianas, these Havaianas are square-toed rather than round. It “gives them that grown-woman feel,” says journalist Devine Blacksher. Blacksher owns two pairs: one for indoors and the other for outdoors (say, running errands around the neighborhood or for pedicure appointments). “I probably wouldn’t wear flip-flops across the city, but for local stuff, they make sense,” she says.
New! You can now save this product for later.
You can often catch Catbird’s chief creative officer, Leigh Plessner, about town in this pair of Havaianas flip-flops. Plessner takes them out of town, too — at the beach, she wears these with nightgowns or a housecoat over a swimsuit when the sun’s out, and silk dresses after sunset. The logo — a flag of Brazil — is a little “silly and winky” when paired with her more formal outfits, she says.
New! You can now save this product for later.
The Lilys from TKees are everything Ruby Buddemeyer, director of copy and concept at Starface, wants in a sandal: low-profile, not loud, easy to throw on. And while the sandals have a thin silhouette, there’s some cushioning in the sole — and, importantly, no break-in time. “I hate breaking in shoes. I tried Birkenstocks a handful of times and can’t handle the break-in,” says Buddemeyer. “These were comfortable right away.” She’s worn them for four summers in a row now.

Take a scroll through one of our typical Strategist 100s — be it the Beauty 100, Travel 100, or Wedding Registry 100 — and you’ll find deeply vetted products that we’ve tested and had on our radar for years. For the Strategist Summer 100, though, we’re doing something a little different. Many of the items here are simply seasonal things we find rather appealing — like a cherry-red linen tank dotted with punchy white buttons or an “adult going-out top” from the Gap — and might just add to our carts. Others are items we already own, like the $20 Uniqlo top that at least three Strategist staffers recently purchased and a pair of water shoes for dry land. There are plenty of clothes, bathing suits, hats, and shoes for women and men (many of which are now on sale as retailers start marking down seasonal items). There are also things for the summer activities you’ll do in those clothes. We’ve got a status cooler and an extra-large picnic blanket. There’s a pop-up firepit. There’s a floating movie screen. And so, with the Fourth of July nigh, let this be your guide to soaking up the height of summer.

argos_summary: The article reviews toddler cups, emphasizing the importance of open or valve‑free straw cups for healthy oral development and hydration. Pediatrician Kaitlin Wiseman advises against sippy cups and valve‑filled straws, recommending durable, leak‑proof, and easy‑to‑clean options made of stainless steel, silicone, or BPA‑free plastic. It highlights product features such as weighted bottoms, high sides, soft silicone straws, and leakproof caps, and discusses how to transition toddlers from bottles to open cups by 18 months. The guide also compares various brands and materials, noting the pros and cons of each for safety, durability, and ease of use.
